comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/statelibraryofnsw] Thanks for putting this pic up...it's a perfect candidate for statue dating! The statues at the Lands Office appear to have originally been the idea of architect James Barnet nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13884682 who envisaged that statues would be placed in all 48 statue niches. As things stand, only the Bridge St facade has its full complement of statues. The Bridge St statues at the Lands Office were added to their niches during 1991-1993 1891-1893. Fortunately, the newspapers of the day ran a number of reports and news items on the statues, and these can now be easily tracked down via the (truly wonderful) NLA digitised newspapers...many of the contemporary newspaper items refer to the sculptor who produced the statue, and in many instances we are informed of a precise date on which particular statues were placed...whilst in other instances the newspaper items provide enough information so that we can arrive at an approximate date on which a statue was placed...and maybe as more newspapers are digitised some dates might be narrowed further. If anyone is interested I've attached the links to my various sources over at this PHM SRNSW pic www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/5401920179/ All up, the various items and reports which appear in the contemporary newspapers indicate that this Fred Hardie album pic was taken in the fairly narrow period from 27/6/1892 (when Bass was added nla.gov.au/nla.news-article112940809) to ca. ? late July or early August 1892 (when Flinders and Sturt were added...in this Fred Hardie pic both Flinders' and Sturt's niches are vacant nla.gov.au/nla.news-article112602891) As of 2013, only 4 statues have been placed in the Gresham St niches...per the digitised newspapers, the Gresham St statues appear to have been added in the period 1901-1902 (still not too sure re Parkes and Martin)...hence all the Gresham St niches are vacant in this pic Whilst the selection of statues might make us cringe slightly today, at a point when narratives of 19th century European exploration have been revisited and re-evaluated and probably deconstructed ad infinitum as well, we need to keep in mind that the Lands Office statues were placed at a time when Australian nationalism was still in its infancy, when nationalist intellectuals were seeking to promote a sense of Australian identity and to develop nationalist narratives based around ideas of exploration and (peaceful) settlement...and at a time when Australian school children grew up reciting the names of kings and queens of England rather than those of the explorers and public figures whose statues feature on the Lands Office facades. www.publicartaroundtheworld.com/Lands_Department_Building... worth checking out

comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] Ahem!  Questioning your "1991-1993" and "PHM pic".  Only typos.  Great work as always!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: I would love to crawl around all the nooks and crannies in this building. I read somewhere that the LH dome was a staff canteen, and originally intended as an observatory. A delightful mish-mash of architectural styles on top, which you never see from the street. Edit - here's the link to the observatory reference (dated 1984) - adsabs.harvard.edu/full/1984PASAu...5..606W

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Does anybody know exactly where the brass Datum Plug in the front (north) wall is?  I think it was installed in 1897 so will not be in this photo.

comment.author: 29029178@N03
comment._content: Our great state government apparently has put the good old Lands Dept (where I started my public service career) up for sale. They said it would suit an upmarket unit complex or a hotel. And apparently he wants to introduce legislation that will override any heritage orders that are on the building.

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/29029178@N03] Bit of a shame (to put it mildly). I gather the Col Sec's Building and the Education Building are also to be sold. I hope the Lands Office doesn't end up as an up-market gambling den with a massage parlour out the back...admirers of fine old buildings will no longer be able to wander around, looking at the statues and other features without being moved on by a security guard...or hassled by some loser who's after a couple of bucks to catch a bus home.
